instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> Missing when Battery Connected
threads.message:
Working on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and can't get it figured out:

1. Board originally had no green light, no power, ppbus/dcin missing, no liquid.
2. Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>/30/35, ISL, <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22 and got my green light and fan spin.
3. Noticed that with (known-good) battery connected, board won't show green light. If I unplug battery, then connect charger, green light is present.
3. Board has green light without battery connected, and will keep green light if I connect battery after board is powered, and board will run from battery. If I plug charger in at this point, no green light again. If I connect battery then connect charger, I get no green light and no power (<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> missing).

Thought this was a pretty clear damaged SMC issue, but even a replacement SMC doesn't resolve issue. What am I missing here? I figured if green light works fine without battery, issue shouldn't be with <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>/<CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, right? 

Any help appreciated, as always. Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> Missing when Battery Connected
threads.message: I would more suspect an issue with <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, pull and inspect/replace again. Also check ACIN voltage, <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> and pull up resistor on ACOK line.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> Missing when Battery Connected
threads.message:
Hey Duke! Thanks so much; you were right on as usual. I checked <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> and it was actually showing me 18.8 [B]k[/B]Ohm and I did not notice that at first. Replaced it, got proper ~19.7ohm, but issue persisted. Realized that with the proper resistance there, <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> then got scorching whenever I'd have battery/charger connected (a hint I wouldn't have had without your tip on <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>!). Replaced <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> and all is well now.

Any idea what would damage <DIODE>D7005</DIODE>/<RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>? Shit charger, or maybe proxy-damage from ISL (from shit charger), or something more? Really appreciate this one, one more for me to document! Thanks so much, Duke.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> Missing when Battery Connected
threads.message: This was done by a shit chinese charger for sure.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> Missing when Battery Connected
threads.message:
Thanks, Duke.

I actually am still having a bit of trouble with this one; it works about 80% of the time. I checked back at my <DIODE>D7005</DIODE>, and noticed some odd diode readings (machine off for 10 minutes before these taken):

<DIODE>D7005</DIODE> diode: pins 1/2: .627; pin 3: .540

<DIODE>D7005</DIODE> on a working board: pins 1/2: 1.80; pin 3: .548

So, pins 1 and 2 are way off of a working board. I'm not quite sure where to go from here; is this maybe an issue with <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> Missing when Battery Connected
threads.message:
Usually <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>, <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> die, also current sense resistor circuits are suspect so check the usual pin 17/18, 27/28.
As you said <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> got hot, that means the ISL is possibly damaged again or <CAPACITOR>C7005</CAPACITOR> is shorting.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> Missing when Battery Connected
threads.message:
Knock-on-wood, I think I got this one resolved finally (hopefully). I ended up replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>, and noticed my diode readings were back to normal. I also replaced a few of the caps around ISL because they just looked "dark", like they had seen a lot of heat. Since doing so, all seems well. Hopefully this will be my last post on this one! ;)

Thanks duke, really appreciate the help.
